content: My research focuses on improving traffic safety and operations in Florida using machine learning methods. Working with Professor Haitham Al-Deek, Ph.D., P.E., my dissertation research focuses on developing a corridor-level approach to traffic safety using both crash and non-crash data to identify high-risk suburban and urban roadways where crashes, especially those resulting in fatalities and serious injuries, can be reduced. Outside of research, I also work as an office assistant in the Academic Affairs Office of the College of Engineering and Computer Science at UCF. When Iâ€™m not working, you can find me playing my Nintendo Switch or wandering around EPCOT.

content: This paper was presented at TRB 2023.
summary: Early detection of disabled and abandoned vehicles using crowdsourced Waze data, namely during morning peak hours and on urban interstates, can help responders reach vehicles sooner before a crash occurs.
title: Improving Law Enforcement and Emergency Response to Disabled Vehicle Crashes Using Waze Crowdsourced Data

summary: A corridor definition was developed and applied to Florida roadways, allowing for expedited network screening and safety improvement identification to reduce fatal and serious injury crashes.

content: This paper was presented at TRB 2023.

title: Statewide Application of Wrong-Way Driving Crash Risk Modeling and Countermeasures Optimization Algorithm to Identify Optimal Locations for Countermeasure Deployment on Florida Limited Access Facilities
